page.title: 12WELLINGBOROUGH SCHOOL(CONT'D
page.content:
unfolds. Batsmen cross over a doorstep once owned by the incomparable Dr. W. G. Grace. Bowlers thunder along a strip of green once trodded by Boris Karloff. The ground is full of ghosts who made the same errors of judgment as the present batsmen who trudges wearily back to the pavilion. It is a microcosm of the whole school. Perhaps ghosts hover in the Common Room, too, where notices are discreet and voices restrained to a low, bass murmur as the same triumphs and disasters are recounted as our forebears knew. Wellingborough School stands as it has stood for centuries, self-assured, self-sufficient, friendly, confident - England at its best, warts and all.
Jim McNicholas. Classics Master.
